questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient is experiencing persistent headaches and frontal sinus pain. A radiograph is taken with the patient in a chin-down position to assess the involvement of the frontal sinus. What is this imaging view called?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Caldwell View

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Caldwell view is specifically designed to visualize the frontal sinuses. In this view, the patient is positioned with the chin down, which projects the frontal sinuses prominently and clearly on the radiograph.
  • Opacification of the frontal sinus, as seen in the image, indicates involvement of this sinus, which is best assessed using the Caldwell view.

 

View

Position

Purpose

Image

Waters' View (Occipitomental View)

(Option A)

Chin-up position.

Best view to visualize the maxillary sinus.

Pierre’s View

(Option B)

Similar to Waters' view but with the mouth open.

Best view to visualize the sphenoid sinus.

Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View)

(Option C)

Chin-down position.

Best view to visualize the frontal sinus.

Lateral View

(Option D)

Lateral (as the name indicates)
  • Allows visualization of all sinuses (frontal, maxillary, sphenoid, and ethmoidal).
  • Helps to understand the pneumatization pattern of the sphenoid sinus.

questions.text:
Identify the structure indicated by the white arrow in the CT scan of the nose and paranasal sinuses shown below



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Haller Cell


 

Explanation:

The white arrow in the image points to the Haller Cell, an ethmoidal air cell located inferomedially near the orbit floor.

 

CT Scan of Nose and Paranasal Sinuses

Initial Cuts (Anterior to Posterior)

Anterior Cut:

  • Structures visible: Nasal cavity, nasal bone structures, cartilaginous septum, and frontal sinus

Progressing cuts:

  • Nasal bones and bony portion of septum
  • Frontal sinus

Middle Region Cuts
  • Maxillary sinus
  • Inferior turbinate and septum
  • Middle turbinate
  • Concha Bullosa (Option D ruled out): Air-filled or pneumatized middle turbinate, which can cause headaches, due to obstruction or irritation of surrounding structures.
  • Ethmoidal air cells
    • Agger Nasi: (Option C ruled out): The anterior-most ethmoidal air cell, visible before the middle turbinate.
    • Bulla Ethmoidalis (EB) (Option A ruled out): The largest ethmoidal air cell, visible further posteriorly.
    • Haller cell: Located inferomedially to the orbit, often extending below the middle turbinate, can contribute to obstruction or sinus issues.

Posterior Cuts

Sphenoid sinus

 

Concha Bullosa

Agger Nasi

Bulla Ethmoidalis (EB)

Haller Cell

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with suspected mastoiditis. The ENT surgeon orders a Law’s view X-ray to assess the mastoid. Which of the following best describes this view?

choices.text: Lateral oblique view with a 15º tilt
Lateral oblique view with a 30º tilt

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lateral oblique view with a 15º tilt

 

Explanation:

  • In Law’s view, the X-ray beam is angled 15º cephalocaudally while the patient’s sagittal plane is kept parallel to the film.
  • This projection helps visualize the mastoid air cells and the external acoustic meatus (EAC).

 

Radiographic Views for Mastoid:

X-ray Projection

Beam Angle & Positioning

Structures Seen

Clinical Applications

Law's View (15° lateral oblique)

Sagittal plane of the skull parallel to the film; 15° cephalocaudal beam angle (Option A).
  • Mastoid air cells
  • External Acoustic Meatus (EAC)
  • Tympanic cavity
  • Evaluation of mastoid air cells
  • Mastoiditis
  • Mastoid pneumatization

Schuller's View (30° lateral oblique)

Similar to Law's view, but the beam is angled 30° cephalocaudal(Option B)
  • EAC superimposed on IAC
  • Mastoid air cells
  • Lateral sinus plate
  • Condyle of mandible
  • Attic-antral region
  • Mastoiditis
  • Destruction of intercellular septa
  • Cholesteatoma
  • Longitudinal petrous fracture

Stenvers View (Axio-anterior oblique posterior)

Head slightly flexed and rotated 45° opposite to the side under examination; beam angled 12° cephalad
  • Posterior cranial fossa
  • Semicircular canals
  • IAC
  • Vestibular system
  • Acoustic neuroma
  • Petrositis
  • Cholesteatoma

Towne's View (30° fronto-occipital axial)

Anteroposterior view with 30° tilt from above and in front. (Option C)
  • Both temporal bones
  • Arcuate eminence
  • Superior semicircular canal
  • Mastoid antrum
  • EAC
  • Tympanic cavity
  • Cochlea
  • Acoustic neuroma
  • Apical petrositis

Transorbital View (AP/PA)

Orbito-meatal line perpendicular to the film; X-ray beam perpendicular to the film from the submental area

EAC, Mastoid air cells, Mastoid process, Cochlea, IAC, Vestibule, Base of skull, Orbital rim

General assessment of mastoid and adjacent structures

Submentovertical View (full axial)

Head and neck hyperextended, orbito-meatal line parallel to the film; beam at right angles to the film

Skull base structures, Mastoid process, Petrous apex, Tympanic cavity

Skull base fractures, mastoid involvement, temporal bone fracture

 

There is no such view as AP view with a 15º tilt (Option D) in mastoid imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding sialography is false?

choices.text: Sialography helps diagnose salivary duct issues.
Contrast dye is injected into the salivary duct.
Restricted dye flow indicates potential salivary stones.
Dye is injected into the salivary gland’s blood vessels.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer:D) Dye is injected into the salivary gland’s blood vessels.

Explanation:

In sialography, the contrast dye is injected directly into the salivary duct, not the blood vessels.

  • This allows visualization of the ductal system and any blockages or abnormalities within it. Sialography:
  • A diagnostic method to evaluate salivary gland duct blockage. (Option A ruled out)

Procedure for Parotid Gland Assessment:

  • Cannulation: The parotid gland duct, located near the upper second molar, is cannulated.
  • Dye Injection: A contrast dye is injected into the duct. (Option B ruled out)
  • X-ray Imaging: An X-ray is taken after dye injection.

Interpreting Results:

  • Unrestricted Dye Flow: Indicates no obstruction in the duct.
  • Restricted Dye Flow: May suggest issues such as:(Option C ruled out)
    • Calculi (salivary stones)
    • Duct ectasia (dilation of the duct)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with severe dysphagia, stridor, and a stiff neck. The physician orders a lateral soft tissue X-ray of the neck as shown. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition on the lateral soft tissue X-ray of the neck?

choices.text: Widening of the Prevertebral Soft Tissue Shadow
Air Bubbles in the Soft Tissues

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Narrowing at the subglottic region.

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and the imaging is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess, which is a collection of pus in the retropharyngeal space.
  • Narrowing at the subglottic region (steeple sign) is a feature of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) and is not associated with retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Retropharyngeal abscess: It is caused by a collection of pus in the retropharyngeal space, typically presenting with symptoms such as severe sore throat, dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), stridor, and a stiff neck.

 

 

Acute Retropharyngeal Abscess

Chronic Retropharyngeal Abscess (Prevertebral Abscess)

Causes
  • Children: Lymphadenitis of lymph nodes of Rouvier
  • Adults: Penetrating injury
  • TB spine (Caries spine)

Clinical features
  • Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing
  • Stridor and croupy cough
  • Torticollis
  • Bulge in posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Discomfort in throat
  • Dysphagia is not marked
  • Posterior pharyngeal wall shows a fluctuant swelling centrally or on one side of midline
  • Neck may show tuberculous lymph nodes

O/E:

Bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall

Unilateral deviation

Diffuse midline

X-ray findings
  • Widening of Prevertebral Soft Tissue Shadow: (Option A)
    • Soft tissue shadow is twice the size of the vertebral body.
  • Straightening of Cervical Spine: (Option C)
    • Loss of normal curvature.
  • Presence of Air Bubbles: (Option B)
    • Indicates possible infection or abscess formation.

X-rays are diagnostic in case of caries of cervical spine

Treatment

IV antibiotics → incision & drainage

Antitubercular treatment

Correct Answer: D) Lyre sign

 

Explanation:

  • This clinical scenario is suggestive of a carotid body tumor (CBT), and the angiogram shows the characteristic Lyre sign.
  • The Lyre sign refers to the splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries due to the tumor at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery.

Carotid Body Tumor (CBT)

Definition & Origin
  • A type of paraganglioma
  • CBTs are benign, slow-growing vascular tumors derived from neural crest cells.

Location

They arise from the carotid body, a small chemoreceptor located at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery.

Epidemiology
  • CBTs are the most common paraganglioma of the head and neck.
  • Familial CBT is associated with mutations in the SDH gene (Succinate Dehydrogenase Complex Gene - SDHB, SDHD).

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless, slow-growing neck mass
  • Symptoms due to compression of nearby structures, such as dysphagia, hoarseness, or a bruit on auscultation.
  • Catecholamine-secreting tumors can cause systemic symptoms like hypertension, palpitations, and sweating.

Imaging
  • CT Angiogram/ DSA: Lyre sign (Option A) - splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries.
  • MRI: Salt and pepper appearance

Management

Surgical resection

 

Phelp Sign (Option A) refers to erosion of the carotico jugular spine between the carotid canal and jugular fossa in glomus jugulare on CT.

Dodd Sign (Option B) refers to the column of air present between the mass and the posterior pharyngeal wall in antro choanal polyp, on lateral x-ray of the skull.

 

Steeple Sign (Option C) is seen on neck X-rays and is associated with croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), showing narrowing of the subglottic airway, resembling the steeple of a church.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the clinic with painful neck stiffness and torticollis four days after undergoing adenoidectomy for chronic adenoiditis. Physical examination reveals restricted neck movement in all directions and a “cock-robin” position of the head. Neurological examination is normal. Which of the following best describes the underlying condition?

choices.text: Traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation following cervical injury
Non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation secondary to infection or surgery
Atlanto-occipital dislocation caused by a congenital cervical spine anomaly
Acute cervical disc herniation causing torticollis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation secondary to infection

 

Explanation:

  • The child developed painful torticollis following a recent adenoidectomy, which is characteristic of Grisel's syndrome.
  • This condition typically occurs due to nontraumatic causes such as an infection or surgery in the head and neck region.

Grisel's Syndrome

Etiology

Nontraumatic atlantoaxial subluxation (Option B), often secondary to upper respiratory infections or post-surgery in the head and neck region (e.g., adenoidectomy).

Pathophysiology

Loosening of the transverse and alar ligaments due to inflammation in the atlantoaxial joint.

Presentation
  • Painful torticollis
  • neck stiffness
  • "Cock-robin" head position.

Imaging

X-ray or CT shows rotational subluxation of C1-C2.

Management
  • Early intervention with bed rest
  • Cervical immobilization
  • Antibiotics
  • Anti-inflammatory agents to prevent neurological sequelae.


 

Complications of adenoidectomy
  • Hemorrhage (most common)
    • Primary hemorrhage: Occurs intraoperatively from the surgical site.
    • Reactionary hemorrhage (within 24 hours of the surgery): occurs due to the displaced clot or slippage of ligature.
    • Secondary hemorrhage(24 hours upto 14 days of surgery): Occurs due to infection.
  • Injury to pharyngeal musculature and cervical vertebrae.
  • Injury to Eustachian tube opening.
  • Grisel's syndrome
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency
  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis
  • Recurrence

 

Grisel's syndrome is specifically a nontraumatic condition, unlike traumatic subluxations caused by direct cervical injury (Option A).

 

Grisel's syndrome involves atlantoaxial subluxation (C1-C2), not atlanto-occipital dislocation (Option C). It can be seen with congenital syndromes such as Down and Marfan which have increased ligament looseness.

 

Cervical disc herniation (Option D) can cause neck pain and radiculopathy but does not explain the specific findings of atlantoaxial subluxation seen in Grisel’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male has a deviated septum with a significant dislocation at the caudal end. The surgeon prefers a unilateral approach, avoiding a full-thickness incision. Which incision is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hemitransfixion incision

 

Explanation:

  • The patient has a caudal septal dislocation, which refers to a deviation or dislocation of the septal cartilage near the base of the nose (caudal end), for which either transfixion or hemitransfixion incision can be used.
  • In this situation, the surgeon wants to access and correct the dislocated part without making an incision through the entire thickness of the septum.
  • Hence, Hemitransfixion incision is appropriate in this scenario.

Types of septal incisions for septoplasty

Killian’s (Option A)
  • In the nasal mucosa, cephalic to the caudal end of the septum
  • Slightly curvilinear incision, 2-3 mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side.

Transfixion (Option C)
  • Through and through incision, close to but caudal to caudal end of the septum.
  • Used in caudal septal dislocation

Hemitransfixion

(Freer’s incision)

(Option B)
  • Same as the transfixion incision but on one side, not through and through.
  • Used in caudal septal dislocation
  • Septocolumellar incision between caudal end of septal cartilage and columella.

Horizontal on the Spur (Option D)
  • For endoscopic spurectomy.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Killian incision kills the septum, more complications, not done frequently
  • Freer's incision -frees the septum, lesser complications, more commonly done

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe nasal obstruction, headaches, and a history of multiple nasal surgeries for chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. On endoscopic examination, there is extensive polyposis with distortion of normal anatomical landmarks. The surgeon decides to use a posterior-to-anterior surgical approach for better access and disease clearance. Which surgical technique is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wigand’s technique

 

Explanation:

The Wigand technique, which proceeds from posterior to anterior, is ideal for cases of extensive polyposis or revision surgeries where anatomical landmarks have been distorted.

In this scenario, the patient has undergone multiple surgeries, making this approach more suitable to ensure complete disease clearance along the skull base and medial orbital wall.

 

Surgical approaches used in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS):

 

Stammberger’s technique (Option A) (Anterior to Posterior):

  • The surgery starts at the uncinate process (anterior part) and moves backward towards the sphenoid sinus.
  • Advantage: It allows the surgeon to tailor the extent of surgery based on the disease's progression. This approach is beneficial in cases of early disease or localized pathology.
  • This is a more conservative technique.

 

Wigand’s technique (Option B) (Posterior to Anterior):

  • The surgery begins at the sphenoid sinus (posterior part) and proceeds forward along the base of the skull and the medial orbital wall.
  • It is typically used in cases of extensive polyposis or during revision surgeries where previous surgeries have altered anatomical landmarks.
  • This technique involves a more aggressive approach, often required for advanced disease with significant anatomical distortion.

 

The Messerklinger approach (Option C) (similar to the Stammberger’s technique) is widely used for managing early disease affecting the anterior sinuses.

 

The Caldwell-Luc procedure (Option D) is a surgical technique used to access the maxillary sinus by creating an opening in the anterior wall of the sinus, typically through the canine fossa. It is commonly performed to remove chronic infections, polyps, or tumors from the maxillary sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements, regarding the different types of mastoidectomy, is CORRECT?

choices.text: Canal Wall Down mastoidectomy preserves the integrity of the postero-superior canal wall
Schwartze’s mastoidectomy is a type of Canal Wall Down mastoidectomy
Modified radical mastoidectomy involves the removal of the postero-superior canal wall
In Canal Wall Up mastoidectomy, the mastoid cavity remains open.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Modified radical mastoidectomy involves the removal of the postero-superior canal wall.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Canal Wall Down mastoidectomy procedures involve removing the postero-superior canal wall, which leads to the creation of a mastoid cavity. Examples include modified radical mastoidectomy and radical mastoidectomy.
  • Canal Wall Up mastoidectomy, such as simple or cortical mastoidectomy, retains the postero-superior canal wall, avoiding the creation of a mastoid cavity.

Types of mastoidectomy:

  1. Traditionally, classified as :
  • Simple (cortical) mastoidectomy
  • Modified radical mastoidectomy
  • Radical mastoidectomy
  1. Depending on whether postero-superior canal is removed or not:
  • Canal Wall Up mastoidectomy (Option D)
  • Canal Wall Down mastoidectomy (Option A)

 

CANAL WALL UP (CWU)

CANAL WALL DOWN (CWD)

Simple/ cortical/Schwartze's Mastoidectomy (Option B)

Modified Radical Mastoidectomy/ Bondy's Procedure (Option C)

Classic Intact Canal Wall, Combined

Approach Tympanoplasty (CAT)

Radical Mastoidectomy
 

Atticotomy
 

Atticoantrotomy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of chronic otitis media. Examination shows a dry tympanic membrane perforation without active infection. She has a 30 dB hearing loss. Which of the following procedures is most appropriate to improve her hearing?

choices.text: Myringoplasty using a temporalis fascia graft

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Myringoplasty using a temporalis fascia graft

 

Explanation:

Myringoplasty is indicated in cases of dry tympanic membrane perforation to restore hearing. A graft such as temporalis fascia is commonly used.

Myringoplasty (Type I tympanoplasty) (Option B)

  • Purpose: Repair of tympanic membrane perforation using a graft (e.g., temporalis fascia, perichondrium, dura, vein, fascia, cadaver membrane).
  • Techniques:
    • Underlay Technique: Graft is placed medial to the perforation and supported by gelfoam.
    • Overlay Technique: Graft is placed lateral to the fibrous layer after removing squamous epithelium.
  • Indications
    • Used to treat conductive hearing loss due to tympanic membrane perforation.
    • Not indicated for treating otitis media with effusion (fluid accumulation without perforation).
  • Hearing Improvement
    • Hearing loss from tympanic membrane perforation: 10–40 dB.
    • Hearing loss from ossicular interruption with an intact tympanic membrane: 54 dB.
  • In chronic otitis media, the procedure is delayed until the ear is dry and free from cholesteatoma (a destructive epithelial growth in the middle ear).

Myringotomy (Option A ruled out)

  • A small incision made in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure due to fluid buildup.
  • Indications:
    • Acute otitis media with pus under tension.
    • Acute suppurative otitis media.
    • Otitis media with effusion (when other treatments fail).

Grommet (Tympanostomy Tube) (Options A & C ruled out)

  • A small tube inserted during myringotomy to facilitate continued fluid drainage.
  • Primarily used to treat otitis media with effusion.

Antibiotic therapy with corticosteroids (Option D): This treatment is useful in active infections but not in repairing perforations or addressing hearing loss.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a chronic middle ear infection presents with a perforated tympanic membrane and erosion of the malleus. Based on Wullstein's classification of tympanoplasty, which type of tympanoplasty would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type II tympanoplasty

 

Explanation:

Type II tympanoplasty involves repairing a perforated tympanic membrane with erosion of the malleus, with the graft placed on the incus or remnant of the malleus, which matches the patient's condition.

Types of Tympanoplasty (Wullstein's Classification)

  • Tympanoplasty: Surgical procedure for eradicating disease and reconstructing the hearing mechanism.
  • It may involve myringoplasty (repair of eardrum) and/or ossiculoplasty (repair of ossicles).
  • Classification based on damaged middle ear parts:

Type

Description

Type I (Myringoplasty)

Repair of a perforated tympanic membrane with a graft. (Option A ruled out)

Type II

Graft placed on the incus or malleus remnant due to malleus erosion. (Option B)

Type III

Graft placed on the stapes head when malleus and incus are absent. (Option C ruled out)

Type IV

Graft placed between the oval and round windows when only the stapes footplate remains; cavum minor created. (Option D ruled out)

Type V

Fenestration in the horizontal semicircular canal, creating a new window with a graft. Performed when stapes footplate is fixed.
  • Tympanoplasty is often combined with mastoidectomy.
  • Performed when the ear is dry and free of cholesteatoma.
  • Modifications mainly involve ossicular reconstruction.

Correct Answer: B) Jansen’s Mastoid Retractor

 

Explanation:

The given instrument is a Jansen’s Mastoid Retractor, which is self retaining and used in mastoidectomy.

Types of Mastoid Retractors

  • Mollison’s Mastoid Retractor: (Option A ruled out)
    • Self-retaining
    • Hemostatic (stops bleeding)

    • (Mnemonic: Mollison has 8 letters , so it has 4*4 teeth for identification)

  • Jansen’s Mastoid Retractor: (Option B)
    • Self-retaining
    • Similar to Mollison’s
    • Use: Both retractors are used after incision and flap elevation to retract soft tissues.

    • (Mnemonic: Jansen has 6 letters, so it ha 3*3 teeth for identification)

  • Lempert’s endaural retractor (Option C): Endaural approach during ear surgery.

  • Lempert’s endaural speculum (Option D): Opens the meatus for endaural incision or local injections.

  • Perkin’s mastoid retractor:
    • Self retaining
    • Hemostatic
    • Use: For retraction of soft tissue during mastoidectomy.

questions.text: Identify the instrument used to reduce fractures of nasal septum.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Asch's Septum Forceps

 

Explanation:

Asch’s forceps are used to reduce fractures of the nasal septum.

Surgical Tools for Nasal Septum Procedures:

Asch's Septum Forceps: (Option C)

  • Reduces fractures.of nasal septum

Walsham’s Forceps: (Option D ruled out)

  • Reduce fractures of nasal bones.

Ballenger Swivel Knives (Option B ruled out)

  • Removes septal cartilage during Submucous Resection (SMR).
  • Features: Rotating blade, various sizes.

Luc's Forceps (Option A ruled out)

  • Removes bone or cartilage during SMR.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of the Saint-Clair Thompson Adenoidectomy Curette?

choices.text: It is held like a dagger in the dominant hand
It is used with limited direct visualization, often blind
It is used without the cage for larger pieces of adenoid tissue
The curette is inserted under the soft palate to remove tissue using an inferior to superior motion.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is used without the cage for larger pieces of adenoid tissue

 

Explanation:

The Saint-Clair Thompson Adenoidectomy Curette is used with a cage to capture and remove adenoid tissue effectively.

Instruments used in Adenoid/ Tonsillectomy

Saint-Clair Thompson Adenoidectomy Curette with Cage

Purpose: Specialized instrument for adenoidectomy to remove adenoid tissue while minimizing trauma.

  • Design:
    • Held like a dagger in the dominant hand. (Option A ruled out)
    • Features a cage to capture adenoid tissue, preventing aspiration into the lungs.
    • Cage can be dismantled for use without it.
  • Types:
    • With Cage: Useful for larger pieces of adenoid tissue. (Option C)
    • Without Cage: Standard version without tissue-holding feature.
  • Technique:
    • Performed blind, with limited direct visualization.(Option B ruled out)
    • A dental mirror or wide-angled rigid endoscope may assist with visibility.
    • Curette inserted under the soft palate, tissue removed using an inferior to superior motion. (Option D ruled out)

Mollison's Tonsillar Dissector and Anterior Pillar Retractor

Purpose: Specialized instrument used in tonsillectomy procedures for enhanced visibility and separation of tonsil tissue.

  • Tonsillar Dissector:
    • Used to separate the tonsil from its surrounding capsule.
    • Facilitates the removal of the tonsil from the tonsillar bed.
  • Anterior Pillar Retraction:
    • Retracts the anterior pillar to improve visibility of the tonsillar fossa.
    • Essential for examining the area for bleeding or remaining tissue post-removal.
  • Additional Uses:
    • Can retract the soft palate and uvula.
    • Aids in overall surgical access and visibility.

Eve's Tonsillar Snare

Purpose: Specialized instrument used in tonsillectomy to remove tonsils and minimize bleeding.

  • Crushing the Tonsil Pedicle:
    • Wire loop tightens around the tonsil's pedicle to crush it.
    • Reduces bleeding by compressing blood vessels.
  • Releasing Coagulation Factors:
    • Crushed tissue releases factors that accelerate coagulation.
    • Further aids in reducing bleeding.
  • Improved Visibility:
    • Enhances visibility of the surgical site by crushing the pedicle.
    • Facilitates complete removal and inspection for remaining tissue or bleeding.
